awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Developing climate-smart irrigation strategies for rice agriculture in Arkansas
awd_abstract_narration:
This research responds to the need to make rice growing more sustainable. Globally rice is the staple food of over 3 billion people yet consumes significant water resources and contributes 10% of anthropogenic methane to the atmosphere. The PI has the long-term career goal to develop sustainable, climate-smart irrigation strategies for rice production while significantly contributing to the education of the next generation of scientists and agricultural professionals. The research objective is to quantify the climate impact of water-saving irrigation strategies, to test their potential scalability, and to encourage more wide-spread implementation of these practices. 

The irrigation practices to be studied create less frequent field inundation, thus they significantly reduce methane that would be produced under flooded conditions (33-98% reductions in methane emission). The research aims to integrate micrometeorological flux observations, rice harvest data, and irrigation practice information to optimize (1) the net reduction in greenhouse gas emissions over a growing season and (2) rice yields, with net reduced costs. The education objective of this proposal is to advance the Environmental and Spatial Technology (EAST) initiative, which is a regionally important project-based, service learning program at middle and high schools. The PI will work with three EAST school programs to collect data useful to the research objectives and to generate a state map to model how changes in land cover can impact groundwater levels and greenhouse gas emissions. This program will help students engage with geospatial science, provide awareness of food and agriculture-related careers and higher education opportunities, and expand perceptions of the food-energy-water nexus.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The research aim of this proposal was to quantify the water, climate, and food impacts of the alternate wetting and drying (AWD) water-saving rice irrigation strategy to test its potential scalability against a variety of landscape and agronomic considerations.

The education aims were to help fill a human capital need by advancing the training of middle and high school students, expand graduate course offerings, and to engage with the public and stakeholders by expanding sustainable rice practices.

My group was able to continuously measure rice field methane dynamics in a pair of long-term sudy sites (production rice fields on a working farm in east-central Arkansas). These measurements were with the benchmark micrometeological method, and also captured carbon dioxide and water vapor (i.e. evapotranspiration) flux dynamics. We were the first to validate this irrigation approach's success in reducing methane fluxes on the production field scale. We additionally measured methane and nitrous oxide fluxes via the closed chamber technique. We have worked in the field with farmers to create different iterations of the alternate wetting and drying irrigation technique, which allowed us to test this practice's impacts in a more nuanced manner. We also worked with satellite products to model the gross primary productivity associated with rice production (i.e. photosynthesis) - important both as a predictor of harvest yield and as an important "fuel" for microbial production of methane (through photosynthetically derived root exudates). The grant also allowed PI Runkle to participate in several methane and flux synthesis activities, including through a USGS Powell Center workshop in Feb 2020. In all, twenty-four peer-reviewed articles were published using the data and ideas generated from this grant; five graduate students and 9 undergraduates were also supported from this grant.

On the education side, we had activities in both aims. Prior to the COVID pandemic, the PI had collaborative relationships with the project-based, service learning program named the Environmental and Spatial Technology (EAST) initiative. These programs were in a middle school in northwest Arkansas and a high school in northeast Arkansas. Collaboration included site visits to each school, participation in tele-conferences about findings, and engagement in designing project-based learning activities. Assessment via pretest and post-test surveys and formative interviews with the teachers and students was conducted by an education specialist. The second aim - engagement with stakeholders - was met through continuous interaction with Field to Market, who creates a farm sustainability tool. I attended their national fall meeting (2022) and met with stakeholders engaged in the rice sector. I also acted as a scientific expert and contributor to a major report associated with a June 2022 meeting in Washington DC on the scienced needed for robust, scalable, and credible Nature based Climate Solutions. This topic area was also the focus of a perspective article I published in 2022, a collaborative article (Novick et al., 2022), and the topic of a one credit-hour honors forum course I taught in fall 2022 at the University of Arkansas.
